data.title: Tabs/Stacks: decide on settings
data.body:
The work on tabs/stacks introduces a new bag of configuration settings. We should decide on the location of these settings and wording. Feedback welcome, I am not attached to the wording I picked currently:
- `workbench.showEditorTabs`: _Controls if opened editors should show in tabs or not_
- `workbench.previewEditors`: _Controls if opened editors show as preview until getting pinned. Set to false to always open editors pinned_
- `workbench.quickOpenPreviews`: _Controls if editors opened from quick open show as preview. Set to false to always open editors from quick open pinned_
- `workbench.editorOpenPositioning`: _Controls where editors open. Select 'left' or 'right' to open editors to the left or right of the current active one. Select 'beginning' or 'end' to open editors independently from the currently active one._

/cc @Microsoft/vscode

data.title: Built in terminal does not correctly work with nvm/npm
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Version 1.2.0 (1.2.0) Current Insiders
- OS Version: OSX

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open the built in terminal
2. Type nvm or npm *

The integrated terminal in the Insider's Builds does not correctly inherit the environment variables that the normal terminal contains. Specifically nvm/npm is not betting picked up. This is not an issue stable build where the terminal works as intended generally, there seem to have been some breaking changes with the terminal since the stable build and it now opens up a "bash" prompt as opposed to my user name and directory.

data.title: No markdown preview button when a file is not named ending with .md
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.0
- OS Version: Windows 7

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open a file named with extension like `.txt`, only if not `.md`.
2. Switch language mode to `Markdown`.

**Now there is no `Preview` button to switch to Markdown Preview view.**

data.title: File associations
data.body:
With VSCode installed, both *.cs and *.xml are shown in Explorer as being of type "Visual Studio Code", so when sorting by type, XML and *.cs files are mixed up. Rinse and repeat with other formats I presume.

No, no, no.

Please fix that.

File associations has plagued Windows for more than 3 decades and still does... :-(

data.title: Debug: Fix setConfiguration error when name is null or undefined
data.body:
Since https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/commit/559f6505004bee38130cfc44368efad3c5291b09.
When I open a new workspace that contains `launch.json`, and press `F5` to debug. It will show a message that `Please set up the launch configuration file for your application.`

Because current `configurationName` is `null`, so we need use the first configuration in `launch.json`.

data.title: Monaco API : `IRichLanguageConfiguration` deleted / renamed but still used in monaco-languages
data.body:
This commit removed/renamed this interface : https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/commit/eca3662d6b8c5a50ef772f9e567e8de3feda8076

This repo still uses it : https://github.com/Microsoft/monaco-languages

Trying to consolidate the two repos into https://github.com/basarat/monaco for use in http://alm.tools/ :rose:

/cc @alexandrudima

data.title: VSCode doesn't show variable value provided by debug adapter in hover if there are variable references
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.0 stable
- OS Version: all

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Have a debug adapter that returns `variablesReference` as part of the `EvaluateResponse` on a hover.
2. The actual tip only shows information in the variables referenced, not the actual value of the main expression to evaluate.

The data tip should also show the value returned for the expression that is being evaluated during a hover.

Note the watch and the hover results:

![hoverbug](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/637952/16028425/02ef548e-3194-11e6-9325-72648bbd51b1.png)

@isidorn @weinand

data.title: Disabled breakpoint reverts the breakpoint to original location (not where it bound)
data.body:
@isidorn @weinand 

We wanted to check what we are seeing is expected.

If a breakpoint is set on line `n`, and that breakpoint bound to line `m`, when the breakpoint is disabled (but the debug session is still running), the glyph goes back to line `n`.

![movingbreakpoint](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/637952/16027159/9e81f872-3188-11e6-8cc6-a9792f67cd78.gif)

VS doesn't behave that way: the disabled breakpoint stays on line `m` until the debugging session is stopped. When the debugging session is stopped, the breakpoint goes back to `n`.

![vsmovingbreakpoint](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/637952/16027261/5da9c4dc-3189-11e6-9c55-5ab6e0617370.gif)

Any thoughts whether it would make sense for VSCode to remember the line a breakpoint bound to and keep that information until the debugging session finishes?

data.title: Clink integrated terminal occasionally drops keystrokes on the UI when using backspace

1. Type a command
2. Press backspace, if you notice a character not being deleted and the cursor jumping back, run the command
3. The command ran will not be equal to the command on the UI

data.title: ALT+SHIFT+LEFT/RIGHT
data.body:
- VSCode Version:1.2.0
- OS Version: OSx 10.11.6 Beta

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open any file
2. Place caret at beginning of a token (word)
3. Press and hold alt+shift
4. When holding alt+shift, press left or right arrow

Expected result: Next token is highlighted.

Actual result: Next character is selected.

Example: 
Caret is represented as `|`. Highlighted text is indicated as `[highlighted text]`.
1. `hello |world`
2. Press ALT+SHIFT+RIGHT
3. Actual: `hello [w]|orld`, expected `hello [world]|`.

When only using ALT+LEFT/RIGHT, the caret jumps past the token as expected.
1. `hello |world` 
2. Press ALT+RIGHT
3. `hello world|`

data.title: Add doctype to webview html
data.body:
Reference: #7626

Not having a doctype declaration can cause some CSS renderings to do weird things.  This is seen for instance in KaTeX as described in #7626.  This will allow KaTeX to render properly in `.previewHTML` invocations.

data.title: Added remove and disable all breakpoints actions to the command palette
data.body: This pull request is the code for issue #7490

data.title: Add Document Types to Webview
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.0
- OS Version: Linux

When providing html to `vscode.previewHtml` the doctype is stripped [here in the webview.html](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/aaa65451f6f2d6de290ee3cb1c8ce1f2def7a52a/src/vs/workbench/parts/html/browser/webview.html#L81).  This can prevent some styles from not working properly, such as KaTeX which can cause problems like [this here](https://github.com/Khan/KaTeX/issues/332).  I was working on a plugin that would allow me to render Markdown and KaTeX in previewHtml when I ran into this issue.

I simply wanted to replace the linked code above with

```
target.contentDocument.write('<!DOCTYPE html>' + newDocument.documentElement.innerHTML);
```

This **does** fix the problem for me.  But I had issues following the contribution guidelines (probably another issue), and there probably is a better way to handle this.

data.title: Can't connect to a debug adapter server when the extension isn't installed in ~/.vscode
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.0-insider
- OS Version: Win 10

I have a debug adapter running in server mode, and an app that is set up to connect with "debugServer" in launch.json. If there isn't an extension that's actually installed, the app will fail to start, with "Configured debug type 'chrome' is not supported". I've been working around that but it's annoying for development. Seems like vscode should skip that check if "debugServer" is set. This isn't a new issue, I think it's always been this way.

data.title: Clink extension for Windows' standard command line not fully supported

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.0
- OS Version: Windows 7 64-bit with Polish language pack

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Install [Clink](https://mridgers.github.io/clink/).
2. Toggle integrated terminal in VSCode.
3. With "clink set option_name value" command, change esc_clears_line to 1 and use_altgr_substitute to 0.
4. Try to use Clink shortcut that require combination of alt + ctrl + _anything_, where _anything_ is a key, that combined with altgr will make a special character on your system. Instead of Clink function, in VSCode integrated terminal you'll see that special character. For me, that's for example __ character, instead of _copy whole line_ function.
5. Try to use alt + h shortcut to show help of Clink. Instead, help menu of VSCode will expand.
6. Try to clear a line with the escape key. Line will be cleared, but terminal will hide.

Clink is very good expansion for Windows' standard cmd, while integrated terminal is very good expansion for VSCode - so I'm really disappointed they aren't fully compatible with each other. Hope you will do something about that.

data.title: Edits made within the peek view do not create an open editor.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Version 1.3.0-insider Commit 51e9802304ee59dcc1d05ec15f26ec5019e28f48
- OS Version: Windows 10 1151

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open a project containing a language supporting "Find All References" (e.g. TypeScript)
2. Ensure there are no open editors in the "EXPLORER" pane.
3. Open a source file.
4. Right-click any declaration and click "Find all references".
5. In the "Find All References" pane, make an edit to a reference in a file that is not the current file.

Outcome:
- The edit is made
- The "OPEN EDITORS" list in "EXPLORER" shows "1 UNSAVED"
- The file with unsaved changes **does not** show up as an open editor.

Expected Outcome:
- The edit is made
- The "OPEN EDITORS" list in "EXPLORER" shows "1 UNSAVED"
- ~~The file with unsaved changes **does not** show up as an open editor.~~
- The file with unsaved changes **does** shows up as an open editor.

data.title: Typing "code" from Start Menu loads inconsistent/confusing experiences

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
I gave a talk at a .NET meetup the other day and one of the attendees told me he struggled to teach new developers in VS Code because when they type "code" from the Start Menu it flashes a command-line window and then loads VS Code (making them think something failed). 

It also has different behavior based on what version of Windows you have (default going to the cmd vs the app):
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1402694/16017047/fc0a4ee4-3152-11e6-9f92-e6bc796c0014.png)
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1402694/16017065/0a49a996-3153-11e6-8b93-f46749afcf37.png)

data.title: Different background colors for different languages in a multi-language file

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
I want to make my multi-language files(such as PHP or ruby on rails) more readable by having different background colors for different languages .

For TextMate it's possible to set particular background color for different scope.[TextMate manual: Theme](https://manual.macromates.com/en/themes), I tried to do it on vscode but it doesn't work.

I also tried the color themes on this blog posts: [Rails TextMate Themes](http://astonj.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/04/view_vibrantink.gif). I still can't get different background colors for the two languages.

data.title: format-on-type indentation places cursor in wrong position

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.0-insider 51e9802304ee59dcc1d05ec15f26ec5019e28f48
- OS Version: MacOS 10.10.5 Yosemite

Steps to Reproduce:
1. install vscode
2. install legacy C# extension
3. set "editor.formatOnType": true, "editor.insertSpaces": false, in user preferences
4. Create a function with no indentation:

```
void Foo()
{
int i = 10
}
```
1. place a semicolon at the end of the variable declaration
2. observe auto-formatted code

expected:
variable declaration indents, cursor remains at the end of the line

```
void Foo()
{
    int i = 10;
               ^ cursor should be here
}
```

observed:
the indentation is performed, but the cursor is left between the 'i' and the '=' causing any additional typing to unexpectedly appear inline

```
void Foo()
{
    int i = 10;
         ^ cursor is here
}
```
